facts.text: Suit filed by landlord-respondent for eviction of tenant-appellant from premises bearing Door No. 188 Old No. 112 at Jawaharlal Nehru Street, Pondicherry

anchor.surface_text: Brief facts which are necessary for the disposal of these appeals are that a suit was filed by the landlord-respondent herein for eviction of the tenant-appellant herein from the premises bearing Door No. 188  Old No. 112  at Jawaharlal Nehru Street, Pondicherry

facts.text: Premises is very old and in a dilapidated condition requiring demolition

facts.text: Another suit filed by landlord on ground that tenant-appellant had ceased to occupy the demised premises under Section 10(2)(vi) of the Pondicherry Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1969

anchor.surface_text: He filed another suit on the ground that the tenant-appellant had ceased to occupy the demised premises under Section 10 2  vi  of the Pondicherry Buildings  Lease and Rent Control  Act, 1969  hereinafter for short the Act .

facts.text: Appellant preferred two separate appeals before the Appellate Authority against Trial Court judgments and decrees

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved against both the said judgments and decrees of the Trial Court, the appellant herein preferred two separate appeals before the Appellate Authority.

facts.text: Appellate Authority reversed both judgments and decrees passed by Trial Court

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Authority reversed both the judgments and decrees passed by the Trial Court.

facts.text: Landlord-respondent preferred two revision petitions before High Court of Madras against orders of Appellate Authority

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ate Court. In support of his submission, he has placed reliance on a decision of this Court in the case of M. Punnoose Vs. K.M. Munneruddin and Others

anchor.surface_text: The expression used in Section 25 of the Act is that the High Court can examine the record of the appellate authority, to satisfy itself as to the regularity of such proceeding or the companyrectness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and if, in any case, it appears to the High Court that any such decision or order should be modified, annulled, reversed or remitted for reconsideration, it may pass orders accordingly. Therefore, the scope of Section 25 of the Act is very wide as the High Court can under this provision examine the record of the appellate authority as to the regularity of such proceeding or the companyrectness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and can modify, annul, reverse or remit for reconsideration. This expression in the Act has a wide import and the very fact that the High Court can examine the companyrectness, legality or propriety of the order necessarily goes to show that the High Court has power to examine the matter with reference to facts also.

concepts.interpretation: Wide scope permitting High Court to examine record for regularity, correctness, legality or propriety of decisions/orders, including re-examination of facts, and power to modify, annul, reverse or remit

arguments.claim: Under Section 25 of the Act, the High Court could not have reversed the finding of fact recorded by the First Appellate Court

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that under Section 25 of the Act a revision petition is maintainable before the High Court and in revision the High Court could not have reversed the finding of fact recorded by the First Appellate Court. In support of his submission, he has placed reliance on a decision of this Court in the case of M. Punnoose Vs. K.M. Munneruddin and Others 2003 10 SCC 610.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ate Court. In support of his submission, he has placed reliance on a decision of this Court in the case of M. Punnoose Vs. K.M. Munneruddin and Others

arguments.court_reasoning: Section 25 confers wide revisional jurisdiction not as narrow as Section 115 CPC, allowing High Court to examine correctness, legality or propriety including facts; quotes and interprets precedent accordingly

arguments.claim: Section 25 of the Act is almost pari materia with Section 25 of the Tamil Nadu Lease and Rent Control Act, 1960

anchor.surface_text: It is true that Section 25 of the Act is almost pari materia with the Tamil Nadu Lease and Rent Control Act, 1960 hereinafter for short the Tamil Nadu Act . Section 25 of the Tamil Nadu Act came up for consideration before this Court in the case of P.M. Punnoose supra

arguments.claim: Revisional jurisdiction under Section 25 is not as narrow as under Section 115 CPC, though findings of fact by Appellate Authority cannot be lightly interfered with

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 of the Tamil Nadu Act came up for consideration before this Court in the case of P.M. Punnoose supra where this Court held that the revisional jurisdiction conferred upon the High Court is not as narrow as one under Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure nevertheless a finding of fact arrived at by the Appellate Authority cannot be lightly interfered with by the High Court acting like a court of appeal and reappreciating the evidence.

arguments.court_reasoning: The approach of the High Court is correct

arguments.claim: Scope of Section 25 is very wide, allowing High Court to examine record for regularity, correctness, legality or propriety of decisions, including re-examination of facts, and to modify, annul, reverse or remit

anchor.surface_text: The scope of Section 25 is not as narrow as Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The expression used in Section 25 of the Act is that the High Court can examine the record of the appellate authority, to satisfy itself as to the regularity of such proceeding or the correctness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and if, in any case, it appears to the High Court that any such decision or order should be modified, annulled, reversed or remitted for reconsideration, it may pass orders accordingly.

arguments.claim: High Court rightly interfered under Section 25 with finding of fact by Appellate Authority as building is about 60 years old and has developed cracks

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in exercise of power under Section 25 of the act has found that the building is about 60 years old and it has developed cracks in it. Therefore, the High Court has rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority and affirmed the judgment and decree of eviction granted by the Trial Court in the suit.

arguments.claim: High Court under Section 25 rightly interfered with finding of fact by Appellate Authority; appeals fail and are dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we are of the opinion that the High Court has under Section 25 of the Act rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority. Consequently, these appeals fail and are dismissed as such.

arguments.claim: No useful purpose served by examining decree of eviction on ground under Section 10(2)(vi) as upheld on Section 25 ground

anchor.surface_text: Since, we have upheld the judgment and order of the High Court on the ground of Section 25 of the Act, we think no useful purpose will be served by going into another issue where the decree of eviction was granted on the ground that the appellant ceased to occupy the premises in terms of Section 10 2 vi .

holdings.text: The scope of Section 25 of the Pondicherry Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1969 is very wide and permits the High Court to interfere with findings of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority by examining the record for regularity, correctness, legality or propriety.

anchor.surface_text: The scope of Section 25 is not as narrow as Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The expression used in Section 25 of the Act is that the High Court can examine the record of the appellate authority, to satisfy itself as to the regularity of such proceeding or the correctness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and if, in any case, it appears to the High Court that any such decision or order should be modified, annulled, reversed or remitted for reconsideration, it may pass orders accordingly. Therefore, the scope of Section 25 of the Act is very wide as the High Court can under this provision examine the record of the appellate authority as to the regularity of such proceeding or the correctness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and can modify, annul, reverse or remit for reconsideration. This expression in the Act has a wide import and the very fact that the High Court can examine the correctness, legality or propriety of the order necessarily goes to show that the High Court has power to examine the matter with reference to facts also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Section 25 showing wide powers to examine correctness, legality, propriety including facts; distinguished from narrower Section 115 CPC; follows precedent on pari materia Tamil Nadu Act provision.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly interfered under Section 25 with the Appellate Authority's finding of fact as the building is about 60 years old and has developed cracks, affirming the Trial Court's decree of eviction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in exercise of power under Section 25 of the act has found that the building is about 60 years old and it has developed cracks in it. Therefore, the High Court has rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority and affirmed the judgment and decree of eviction granted by the Trial Court in the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of wide revisional powers under Section 25 to re-examine evidence on building's dilapidated condition; accepts High Court's factual finding based on record.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly interfered under Section 25 with the finding of fact by the Appellate Authority; consequently, the appeals fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we are of the opinion that the High Court has under Section 25 of the Act rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority. Consequently, these appeals fail and are dismissed as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirms correctness of High Court's exercise of revisional jurisdiction and interference with factual finding, leading to dismissal of appeals.

holdings.text: No useful purpose will be served by examining the decree of eviction on the ground under Section 10(2)(vi) since upheld on Section 25 ground.

anchor.surface_text: Since, we have upheld the judgment and order of the High Court on the ground of Section 25 of the Act, we think no useful purpose will be served by going into another issue where the decree of eviction was granted on the ground that the appellant ceased to occupy the premises in terms of Section 10 2 vi .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural decision not to address alternative ground as primary issue resolved in favor of eviction.

anchor.surface_text: The scope of Section 25 is not as narrow as Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The expression used in Section 25 of the Act is that the High Court can examine the record of the appellate authority, to satisfy itself as to the regularity of such proceeding or the correctness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and if, in any case, it appears to the High Court that any such decision or order should be modified, annulled, reversed or remitted for reconsideration, it may pass orders accordingly. Therefore, the scope of Section 25 of the Act is very wide as the High Court can under this provision examine the record of the appellate authority as to the regularity of such proceeding or the correctness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and can modify, annul, reverse or remit for reconsideration. This expression in the Act has a wide import and the very fact that the High Court can examine the correctness, legality or propriety of the order necessarily goes to show that the High Court has power to examine the matter with reference to facts also.
Consequently, these appeals fail and are dismissed as such.
